results.title: Jesus Christ superstar
results.creator_credit: Norman Jewison, Robert Stigwood and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description: Andrew Lloyd Webber and Tim Rice’s rock opera, “Jesus Christ Superstar” is one of the most successful theatrical musicals of all time. The story of Jesus’s Passion is scored to a vibrant, electronic rock beat and is performed by a cast of dancers and singers. The tribal aesthetics of the hippies and the counter-culture are as integral to the work as is the story of the Gospels. Filmed on location in Israel, the movie version of the opera is a pyrotechnic feast with dazzling editing and photography. Finally, however, it is the strength of the music and libretto by which this work has to be judged. The performances of Yvonne Elliman as Mary Magdalene and Carl Anderson as Judas are outstanding. Through their singing, the full tragedy and power of the Passion is realised. Songs include” “Jesus Christ Superstar”, “What’s the Buzz” and a knockout rendition of “I Don’t Know How to Love Him” by Elliman. Melvyn Bragg co-wrote the screenplay with Norman Jewison.

results.title: Young man with a horn
results.creator_credit: Michael Curtiz, Jerry Wald and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: Kirk Douglas plays the talented trumpeter, Rick Martin, loosely based on the life of jazz great, Bix Beiderbecke. Rick is a poor white orphan who learns the power of jazz through scouting the black neighbourhoods of his city. He comes in contact with a trumpet player (the brilliant jazz trumpeter Hoagy Carmichael) who teaches him how to play. His genius for the trumpet leads Rick to gigs with all-white orchestras and combos but he aches to play the sensual jazz music he adores. His battle between the demands for material success and his love for music leads him to alcoholism and a life on the streets. Co-starring Lauren Bacall as the rich society woman who Rick marries and who betrays him and Doris Day as the one woman who really understands his love for jazz. “Young Man With a Horn” features some fantastic black and white camerawork on New York locations and a great jazz and popular music score, including the songs “With A Song in My Heart”, “Get Happy” and “Love for Sale”. Based on the novel by Dorothy Baker.

results.title: Robocop
results.creator_credit: Paul Verhoeven, Arne Schmidt and Orion Pictures Corporation
results.brief_description: In the corrupt, crime-ridden Detroit of the future, a multi-national conglomerate has assumed control of the Police Department. Law is now a business and proft essential. When Officer Murphy, (Peter Weller) is brutally murdered by vicious criminals, his body is transformed into a cyborg: Half-man, Half-robot - ROBOCOP. Equipped with the fastest reflexes modern technology can offer, onboard computer-assisted memory and a lifetime of on-the-street law enforcement, ROBOCOP launches into a relentless quest to serve, uphold and protect. Features non-stop action, comic book humour and electrifying special effects. Co-starring Nancy Allen, Daniel O’Herlihy, Ronny Cox, Kurtwood Smith and Miguel Ferrer.

results.title: King of the hill
results.creator_credit: Steven Soderbergh, Albert Berger, Barbara Maltby, Ron Yerxa, Gramercy Pictures and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description: After the post-modern dissection of contemporary sexual mores in “Sex, Lies and Videotape” this touching and elegant film, set in 1933 during the height of the Depression, is a wonderful surprise. Aaron (Jesse Bradford) is a young, imaginative Jewish boy whose father is an unemployed salesman and whose mother is hospitalised for tuberculosis. Initially, Aaron is relatively numbed to the devastations of poverty but as his own family descends further into unemployment, the safe confines of his world are slowly stripped away. “King of the Hill” is a homage to the romantic cinema of Capra and Wellman but it does not flinch from expressing the darker undercurrents of poverty. The supporting cast includes Jeroen Krabbe and Lisa Eichhorn as the parents, Karen Allen, Spalding Gray and Elisabeth McGovern. The soundtrack comprises popular songs of the thirties. Based on the Depression memoirs of A.E. Hotchner.

results.title: Altered states
results.creator_credit: Ken Russell, Howard Gottfried and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: William Hurt is Dr. Eddie Jessup, a scientist obsessed with the most enigmatic of questions: What is God? What is consciousness? How did life begin? His research leads him to experiments with sensory deprivation, schizophrenia, and finally with Native American hallucinogenic drugs which have been used in religious ritual for eons. As his experiments progress Eddie finds himself regressing further into the primordial past and bringing it back into his present. Ken Russell directs with his own hallucinogenic urgency, creating a pop fusion of horror film, psychedelic religiosity, existentialism and sheer knuckle-biting suspense. Wildly misunderstood on its release, “Altered States” is a fascinating movie roller-coaster grounded by a devilish sense of humour which refuses to allow the film to drift into pomposity or kant: this is Frankenstein on LSD. Blair Brown is Dr. Jessup’s equally brilliant but despairing wife. The enigmatic, frightening music score is by renowned composer John Corigliano.

results.title: War and peace
results.creator_credit: King Vidor, Dino De Laurentiis, Paramount Pictures and Ponti-De Laurentis
results.brief_description: Based on Leo Tolstoy’s 20th Century masterpiece, it took a decade of preparation and two years of filming to produce this classic version. The personal stories of many characters, love affairs, and philosophies are woven throughout this massive and intricate tapestry of Russia during Napoleon’s invasion at the turn of the 19th Century. With great attention to detail and historical accuracy, this epic becomes an unforgettable document as well as a highly moving drama.

results.title: The Lady from Shanghai
results.brief_description: Orson Welles never played by Hollywood’s rules. This startling film, which begins as a conventional film noir, turns into a sumptuous exploration of the visual possibilities of cinema. The lighting, cinematography, sound and editing have the austerity and beauty of a classical score. Rita Hayworth is the ambiguous centre of the film, a “femme fatale” whose behaviour continually disturbs the expectations of the viewer, as much as it confuses her obsessed lover, Michael (Orson Welles). On its release the film shocked Hollywood. Its eroticism is intense and arousing; the central characters amoral and violent. Initially maligned, the film helped destroy Welles Hollywood career but its power remains undiminished and in Europe it was quickly recognised as one of the masterworks of American cinema. Justly famous for its thrilling climax in a Hall of Mirrors, “The Lady of Shangai” is a rivetting suspense film with moments of dazzling beauty and virtuosity. Based on the novel by Sherman Woods.

results.title: Sunset Boulevard
results.creator_credit: Billy Wilder, Charles Brackett and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: This scathing film about Hollywood morality stars William Holden as an aspiring screenwriter who becomes a gigolo for fading movie Goddess, Norma Desmond (Gloria Swanson). A beauty of the silent screen she now remains isolated in her Los Angeles mansion, remembering the days when her fame was celebrated throughout the world. With a cynical, erudite script and some of Wilder’s best direction, “Sunset Boulevard” is a classic about the decay of Hollywood’s Golden Age. As the central character willing to prostitute himself in order to succeed, Holden is excellent but it is Swanson who gives one of the screen’s greatest performances as the demented, dangerous Norma. Her final scene is unforgettable.

results.title: Malcolm X
results.creator_credit: Spike Lee, Marvin Worth, 40 Acres and a Mule Filmworks and Largo Entertainment
results.brief_description: Malcolm X was one of the most controversial American political figures. Based on Alex Haley’s “The Autobiography of Malcolm X”. It is a landmark film in that it has an African-American as the hero of a Hollywood epic. Malcolm X was initially a small-time crim who converted to Islam and became a central figure in the the Civil Rights Movement in the 1960s. A passionate and dynamic speaker, his vehement condemnation of race relations fightened and incensed many white Americans. The film faithfully follows Malcolm X’s life: his poor childhood and violent early adulthood, his prison years, his involvement in the Nation of Islam and the Civil Rights Movement, and the lead-up to his assassination. Though a long film of the epic genre, Spike Lee’s direction is colourful and well-paced, and some of the sequences are dazzling, including the pilgrimmage to Mecca. Spike Lee was the first Western filmmaker allowed to film in the Holy City. “Malcolm X” reclaims, with passion and dignity, the life of a controversial but inspiring man. Denzel Washington plays Malcolm X and Angela Bassett plays his wife. Cast alson includes Al Freeman Jr, Albert Hall, Delroy Lindo.

results.title: Fahrenheit 451
results.creator_credit: Francois Truffaut, Lewis M. Allen and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description: Truffaut’s first English language film, and his first film shot in colour, is a visually elegant science fiction story about a future in which television dominates people’s lives and where books are forbidden. Montag (Oskar Werner) burns books for a living. He and his wife Linda live in an opulent suburban house where she takes pills to calm her while she interacts with the giant TV screen on her wall. Montag is bored but unaware of the nature of his alienation until he meets a radical schoolteacher on a train. Soon he picks up a forbidden book and begins reading. Under-rated on its original release, the film now impresses with a visually experimental colour palette and stark futurist sets which imaginatively represent the landscape of a technological fascism. Based on Ray Bradbury’s chilling novel, which itself was influenced by the book-burnings of totalitarianism, the film version now seems prophetic of our contemporary world where telecommunications are changing the nature of our immediate, physical interaction with the world. Julie Christie impresses in a difficult duel performance as Linda and as the schoolteacher.
